content.text:
# Embassy of the United Kingdom, Yangon

| ambassador   = Pete Vowles (as of 2025)
| website      =
}}
The Embassy of the United Kingdom, Yangon, also called the British Embassy Yangon, is the United Kingdom’s main diplomatic mission to the Republic of the Union of Myanmar. Located at 80 Strand Road in Kyauktada Township, the embassy plays a key role in bilateral relations between the UK and Myanmar, including political dialogue, development assistance, trade cooperation, and consular services for British nationals.
History
The origins of the British diplomatic presence in Myanmar date back to the colonial period, when Yangon (then Rangoon) served as the capital of British Burma. A colonial-era building on Strand Road became home to the British Embassy after Myanmar's independence in 1948.
It also hosted the British Council, which operated the country’s only English-language library during the 1980s—a rare space for accessing uncensored Western media and a free photocopier.
In August 1988, the embassy played an indirect role in Myanmar’s pro-democracy uprising. On 8 August, striking dockworkers marched to the building and symbolically laid down their tools, marking the start of a nationwide strike that catalyzed the 8888 Uprising.
Following the relocation of Myanmar’s administrative capital to Naypyidaw in 2005, the embassy remains based in Yangon, which continues to function as the country's commercial and cultural hub. The British ambassador and staff work closely with both local government officials and civil society organizations from this historic base.
In recent years, the UK has been actively involved in advocating for democratic transition and human rights in Myanmar, especially following the 2021 military coup. The embassy has issued public statements, engaged with international partners, and supported civil society groups under challenging political conditions. In August 2021, Pete Vowles as appointed as the British ambassador to Myanmar. He did not present his credentials to the Burmese military junta, the State Administration Council, despite repeated requests from the junta. In response, the British government downgraded Vowles’ title from ambassador to chargé d’affaires ad interim, but the Burmese military junta refused to accept the British designated envoy as chargé d’affaires.
Architecture
The embassy occupies a prominent colonial-era building on Strand Road, adjacent to other key diplomatic and commercial sites. Originally built in 1900 as the Rangoon headquarters of the J&F Graham Shipping Company, this elegant colonial-era structure was designed by Thomas Swales and constructed by Robinson & Mundy. Located on a prominent stretch of Strand Road, the building features lattice windows and an entrance awning, and has remained in excellent condition due to its diplomatic ownership.
Ambassadors
The British ambassador to Myanmar is appointed by the Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO).
Previous ambassadors include:
*Vicky Bowman (2002–2006)
*Andrew Patrick (2013–2017)
*Dan Chugg (2018–2021)
See also
* Foreign relations of Myanmar
* Embassy of Myanmar, London
* United Kingdom–Myanmar relations
